Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story: I stared at the calendar on my phone, the bright circle around Saturday glaring at me. My daughter had reminded me twice already: “Dad, don’t forget, everyone’s coming over. The kids are so excited to see you.” I could almost hear my grandson’s laughter, feel his small hand tugging at mine, begging me to play. But as I scrolled through my emails, a new message from my colleague popped up—another reminder that the report I was working on needed to be finished by Monday morning. If I didn’t get it done, the whole project would stall, and my teammate would be left scrambling. I could sense the unspoken pressure from my team, the expectation that I’d pull my weight, just as I always had. My chest tightened as I imagined disappointing my family or letting down my colleagues. I wanted to be present for my grandchildren, to be the reliable grandfather they looked forward to seeing. But I also didn’t want to be the weak link at work. The two worlds pulled at me, each demanding more than I felt I could give.
